docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of people could be steered toward treatment for depression if their regular doctors took a few moments to ask them two simple questions, a study reported yesterday. The first question could not be more direct: ''Are you currently sad or depressed.'' The second: ''Are the things that previously brought you pleasure no longer bringing you pleasure?''
docs.abstract: Study by University of North Carolina researcher Michael Pignone, prepared for federal Preventive Services Task Force and reported in Annals of Internal Medicine, recommends that primary care doctors screen patients to determine whether they are depressed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Thousands of people could be steered toward treatment for depression if their regular doctors took a few moments to ask them two simple questions, a study reported yesterday.    The first question could not be more direct: ''Are you currently sad or...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the early 80's, Bob, who was a student at the time, decided to donate sperm to a sperm bank. He needed the money, but he also thought it would be nice to help a couple who wanted a child but could not conceive. He signed a waiver and was promised anonymity. He assumed that was that. But this year, the sperm bank contacted Bob, who asked that his last name and hometown be withheld, and told him that he had a daughter who wanted to meet him. ''I was bowled over, and even suspicious at first,'' Bob said.

headline.main: Once-Invisible Sperm Donors Get to Meet the Family

docs.abstract: Article on sperm banks across US, following option first offered by Sperm Bank of California in Berkeley, that are finding ways to assure that children born with donated sperm can meet men who fathered them; options being offered by some sperm banks in US described; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study raises the possibility that soy-based infant formulas, which account for one-fourth of all the formula used in the United States, may weaken babies' immune systems. The warning comes in a study being published today in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. But the lead author, Dr. Paul S. Cooke of the University of Illinois, took pains to say there was no proof that soy formulas were harmful. ''We are absolutely not saying these kids have been harmed, or are being harmed,'' Dr. Cooke said.

headline.main: A Closer Look at Soy and Babies

docs.abstract: Study led by University of Illinois researcher Paul Cooke, published in latest issue of Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences, warns that soy-based infant formulas may weaken babies' immune systems (M)
docs.snippet: A new study raises the possibility that soy-based infant formulas, which account for one-fourth of all the formula used in the United States, may weaken babies' immune systems.    The warning comes in a study being published today in The Proceedings...

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers in Britain say they have found no evidence that cleaning, even heavy housework, causes women between the ages 60 and 79 to lose weight. The study found that even heavy housework -- which could include vacuuming, scrubbing floors or washing windows -- had no health benefit. It defined light housework as cooking, washing up, dusting and so on.

headline.main: No Gains From a Clean Home

docs.abstract: Study led by University of Bristol researcher D A Lawlor, published in Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, finds no evidence that cleaning, even heavy housework, provides any health benefit, including weight loss, to women between ages 60 and 79; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Researchers in Britain say they have found no evidence that cleaning, even heavy housework, causes women between the ages 60 and 79 to lose weight.    The study found that even heavy housework -- which could include vacuuming, scrubbing floors or...

docs.lead_paragraph: Consider the consequences of a garbage strike. Trash accumulates, streets are clogged and daily life is disrupted. Eventually, things can come to a standstill. Scientists say that kind of disruption may lie at the heart of a wide array of diseases afflicting millions of Americans.

headline.main: In Folding Proteins, Clues to Many Diseases

docs.abstract: Article on new research into understanding of how proteins in blood fold; folding is constant process in which strings of amino acids form specific shapes to perform myriad tasks; as many as third of proteins end up misfolded; Harvard Medical School neurology Prof Peter Lansbury is focusing role protofibrils, made up of tiny spheres of misfolded proteins, may play in development of Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, diabetes and other amyloid diseases; photos; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Consider the consequences of a garbage strike. Trash accumulates, streets are clogged and daily life is disrupted. Eventually, things can come to a standstill.    Scientists say that kind of disruption may lie at the heart of a wide array of diseases...

docs.lead_paragraph: Foot ulcers can be the bane of diabetics, in many cases forcing doctors to amputate a lower limb to prevent further damage. To combat this, diabetics with such problems are routinely counseled to wear therapeutic footwear, and insurance companies and Medicare regularly cover much of the cost.
docs.abstract: Study led by Department of Veterans Affairs researcher Gayle Reiber concludes that use of therapeutic footwear does not help reduce recurrence of foot ulcers in diabetics; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Foot ulcers can be the bane of diabetics, in many cases forcing doctors to amputate a lower limb to prevent further damage.    To combat this, diabetics with such problems are routinely counseled to wear therapeutic footwear, and insurance companies...

docs.lead_paragraph: Leg braces and crutches: in America, they symbolize polio epidemics long past. But well after the disease had become an abstraction to children here, it remained a reality in other countries. In 1988, 350,000 children were paralyzed by polio. That year, the World Health Organization began a global vaccination campaign, with the goal of wiping out the disease by the end of 2000.

headline.main: The Worldwide Push to Put an End to Polio

docs.abstract: World Health Organization, reporting only 600 cases of polio in 2001, sets new goal to wipe out disease this year so that it can be officially declared eradicated by 2005; photos by special representative of Unicef, Brazilian photojournalist Sebastiao Salgado, who accompanied vaccinators, can be seen online and at Aperture's Burden Gallery in Manhattan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like many people taking drugs to combat H.I.V., Steven Hodges, a former hairdresser here, noticed a few years ago that he was becoming gaunt and hollow-cheeked even though he still felt healthy. ''I didn't feel sick, and I didn't want to look sick,'' he said. ''But all my clients kept saying, 'Are you O.K.?' -- which doesn't make you feel any better.''

headline.main: H.I.V. Patients Try to Remedy Gaunt Appearance

docs.abstract: Article on treatments being offered to HIV and AIDS patients to ease lipodystrophy, disruption of body's methods of processing and distributing fat that results in loss of fat on face and accumulation of fatty tissue on shoulders and around neck and belly; corrective procedures, including liposuction and plastic surgery, are not cheap and insurance companies generally refuse to cover costs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Getting the Sex You Want: A Woman's Guide to Becoming Proud, Passionate and Pleased in Bed,'' by Dr. Sandra Leiblum and Judith Sachs, Crown, $23.95. ''The New Love and Sex After 60,'' by Dr. Robert N. Butler and Dr. Myrna I. Lewis, Ballantine, $14.95. Sexual interest may be instinctive and omnipresent but, alas, as an old joke has it, there are those who are in for a sexless fall because they have winter in their hair, or lack summer in their hearts and spring in their bones. Seriously put, age, medical or emotional problems, ignorance, ambivalence, restraint, boredom, disappointment, lack of partners or the prevalence of indifferent ones, all conspire to ruin sex lives.

headline.main: Guides to Help Revive The Sexually Inactive

docs.abstract: John Langone discusses two books: Getting the Sex You Want: A Woman's Guide to Becoming Proud, Passionate and Pleased in Bed by Dr Sandra Leiblum and Judith Sachs and The New Love and Sex After 60 by Drs Robert N Butler and Myrna I Lewis; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: My father died suddenly of his second heart attack while shopping for groceries. Though he was a very sweet and caring man, patience was not his strong suit, and my mother was convinced that his irritation over being stuck behind a garbage truck on the way to the store ultimately did him in.

headline.main: Ancient Tool of Survival Is Deadly for the Heart

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on possibility of strong relationship between excessive emotional stress and elevated risk of developing and dying of heart disease; explains how autonomic nervous system's fight-or-flight response works and describes ways to curb overactive sympathetic nervous system; drawing (M)
